Evaluation_Questions: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Comments_Questions: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
Comments_List: Good dialect vocabulary! Knowledge of the origin of words in dialect. Conversational skills.
This course provided insight into colloquial Arabic words and phrases that I hope will be useful in the future. I got used to colloquial sentence structure as well.
I gained speaking and comprehension proficiency in Levantine Arabic
This class helped develop and apply basic levantine dialect skills, spoken and listening.  Most of the Arabic language was pretty basic, but it was nice to have a class space to practice speaking.
Better knowledge and understanding of Levantine dialect, new vocabulary.
More natakallam in the future. The practice with native speakers was great. I wish it was taught more often because Im in L5 and there were students of many levels.

This might sound strange but I actually think it would help if the course had more evaluations (i.e. quizzes) to help students retain the material. I liked the emphasis on talking in class a lot. I think it wouldve been helpful if we had more structured questions to ask each other that focused on the vocab so that we had to use the vocabulary in sentences. I think the exercise where we were given scenarios on slides and had to use vocab phrases was very helpful.

The conversational elements are the strongest aspects of the course the Levantine table especially is helpful. The projects often felt a little like busy work, and I wish we spent more time on the grammar and activating new vocabulary.
This class had very little outside work and was mostly class based discussion.   A little more outside work could be useful for the class.
A bit less reliance on the book, and more outside content.
Yes!! Only dialect class opportunity for Arabic

Yes, because this is a great opportunity to spend time on the Levantine dialect which there often isnt time for in the normal Arabic sequence. You will get good speaking practice, and the workload is very manageable. If you want to learn new vocab you will have to encourage yourself to practice it because there are no formal assessments besides projects so Im not sure how much of the new vocab I retained.
Yeah, if you want to learn Levantine Arabic, this is your best bet at Yale.
Yes, Sarab is an incredible professor and so nice--she really encourages students to speak in class and practice! Workload is very minimal and manageable.

Yes; I think learning a dialect is extremely important when it comes to Arabic, and I was glad that Yale offers the chance to do so. I think this is something that distinguishes Yale's Arabic program and I hope it will be mantained in the future.
